text.__SUMMARY__: Scaevola collaris is a shrub in the family Goodeniaceae and its native range is five mainland states/territories of Australia: the Northern Territory, New South Wales, South Australia, Queensland and Western Australia.It is an endangered species in New South Wales.
text.Description:
Scaevola collaris is an erect shrub, growing to 0.5 m. The stems are erect and smooth. The leaves are sessile (i.e., have no stalk), succulent and smooth, and 1-8.5 cm long by 1-9 mm wide.
The flowers occur in terminal spikes or are solitary or clustered in the axils.The sepals are ovate to triangular, smooth and almost free. The corolla is 6-17mm long, smooth on the outside with short hairs on the inside, and yellow to cream or mauve. The anthers are free.
The ovary is inferior and from 5-20 mm long, is two-celled and usually has a beak and a foot.It flowers mostly from May to November.
text.Distribution: It is found on saline soils in the arid parts of the south of Western Australia, the south of the Northern Territory, South Australia, western Queensland and north-western New South Wales.
text.Naming: It was first described in 1859 by Ferdinand von Mueller, and the specific epithet, collaris, comes from the Latin, collaris (having a collar).
